title: Narrowing the treatment gap with equitable access: mid-term outcomes of a community case management program in Cameroon
authors: Littrell M, Moukam LV, Libite R, Youmba JC, Baugh G
intervention:
Community case management for childhood ilnesses. CCM package provided
community-based diagnosis, treatment and referral for suspected
malaria with artemisinin combination therapy (ACT)
and diarrhoeal disease with ORS and zinc through community health workers (PSI)
outcomes-bf:
Awareness, access and attitudes towards CHW
services among caregivers improved with intervention
outcomes-behavior:
Children living in intervention vs comparison
areas were significantly more likely to receive treatment
at a public health facility or through a CHW for fever  and diarrhoea

Appropriate treatment was significantly higher among children
in intervention vs comparison areas including: antimalarial
treatment for fever , ACT
for fever , ORS for
diarrhoea and zinc for
diarrhoea

title: Improvements in access to malaria treatment in Tanzania following community, retail sector and health facility interventions -- a user perspective
authors: Alba S, Dillip A, Hetzel MW, Mayumana I, Mshana C, Makemba A, Alexander M, Obrist B, Schulze A, Kessy F, Mshinda H, Lengeler C
population: Treatment-seeking surveys of people who had suffered a fever case in  the previous 14 days
intervention: Social Marketing for improved treatment seeking
outcomes-bf:
Improvements in understanding causes of malaria (from 62% to 84%); higher treatment coverage
with anti-malarials (86% to 96%)
outcomes-behavior: Increases in health facility attendance as first treatment option for patients older than five years (27% to 52%);  more timely use of anti-malarials (80% to 93-97% treatments taken within 24 hrs).

title:
Household ownership and use of insecticide treated nets among target groups after implementation of a national voucher programme in the United Republic of Tanzania:
plausibility study using three annual cross sectional household surveys
authors: Hanson K, Marchant T, Nathan R, Mponda H, Jones C, Bruce J, Mshinda H, Schellenberg JA
intervention: Social marketing combined with the National Voucher Scheme targeting mothers of young children at antenatal clinics
outcomes-behavior: Among infants under 1 year of age, use of an ITN increased from 16% to 34%

title: Access to artemisinin combination therapy for malaria in remote areas of Cambodia
authors: Yeung S, Van Damme W, Socheat D, White NJ, Mills A
population: Individuals with a  history of  fever in the last three weeks in areas with village  malaria workers (VMWs), outreach clinics, and in areas with no  intervention
intervention:
Social marketing of
blister-packaged artesunate and mefloquine (Malarine ®)
and RDTs  through VMWs and outreach
outcomes-behavior:
Only
17% of individuals in non-intervention areas reported having had a biological diagnosis for their most recent episode of illness. This was significantly higher in the areas with VMWs (63%) and outreach (35%);  VMWs and outreach workers reported always using RDTs. In contrast, only 15%  of tests at
private health facilities and 69%  public health facilities were by RDT; VMW scheme and outreach significantly increased the likelihood of being seen by a trained provider (Adjusted
Odds Ratios (AOR) of 148 and 4 respectively) and of receiving A+M (AORs of 2.7 and 7.7 respectively).
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Competition, Segmentation,  Methods mix

title:
Distribution Systems of Insecticide-Treated Bed Nets for
Malaria Control in Rural Burkina Faso: Cluster-
Randomized Controlled Trial
authors: Müller O, De Allegri M, Becher H, Tiendrebogo J, Beiersmann C, Ye M, Kouyate B, Sie A, Jahn A
intervention: Subsidized ITN distribution through social marketing with or without free ITN distribution (free distribution took place through antenatal clinics)
outcomes-bf: ITN ownership increased in SM with free distribution areas more than in SM only areas from  baseline  to  follow-up
outcomes-behavior: Increases in Bednet use in previous night was similarly higher in both groups from baseline to follow-up; use among pregnant women and children under five increased in SM with free distribution from   44% to 50% and in SM only from 37% to 44%.

title:
Effect of expanded insecticide-treated bednet coverage on child survival in
rural Kenya: a longitudinal study
authors: Fegan GW, Noor AM, Akhwale WS, Cousens S, Snow RW
intervention: Combined approach of social marketing and free distribution of ITNs
outcomes-behavior:
Increase in ITN use by children aged less than 5 years from 7% in 2004, to 23·5% in
2005, to 67% in 2006
outcomes-health:
ITN use
was associated with a 44% reduction in mortality

title:
Sustained high coverage of insecticide-treated bednets through
combined Catch-up and Keep-up strategies
authors: Grabowsky M, Nobiya T, Selanikio J
population: Households with at least one child less than 5 years of age
intervention:
Mass, free distribution (Catch-up) of insecticide-treated bednets (ITNs) during measles
vaccination campaigns, followed by antenatal clinic-based social marketing for routine Keep-up on ITN coverage and use
outcomes-bf:
95.7% of children slept in a household that had a net, 86.1% slept in a household that had a campaign
net
outcomes-behavior: 59.6% of children slept under an ITN

title: Increasing coverage and decreasing inequity in insecticide-treated bed net use among rural Kenyan children
authors: Noor AM, Amin AA, Akhwale WS, Snow RW
location: Bondo, Greater Kisii, Kwale, and Makueni Districts, Kenya
intervention: At baseline only commercial social marketing (PSI) was in place.  Heavily subsidized MCH clinic distribution (PSI) and free distribution were  implemented during the  course of the study
outcomes-behavior: At baseline only 7% of  children slept under a net treated with insecticide within 6 months the night before the survey. At 12 months, this increased to  23% and at 24 months this  increased to  67% with the  majority of ITNs obtained via free distribution and heavily subsidized distribution  at MCH clinics

title: The effect of delivery mechanisms on the  uptake of bed net re-impregnation in Kilifi District, Kenya
authors: Snow RW, McCabe E, Mbogo CN, Molyneux CS, Some ES, Mung'ala VO, Nevill CG
intervention: Retreatment of ITNS was initially offered for free house-to-house, then free at sentinel sites, and then through social marketing and sales
outcomes-behavior: Net re-impregnation coverage decreased from 97% during free house-to-house delivery to 61-67% when free re-treatment moved to sentinel sites to 7% after the social marketing model was implemented

title: The impact of a hybrid social marketing intervention on inequities in access, ownership and use of insecticide-treated nets
authors: Agha S, Van Rossem R, Stallworthy G, Kusanthan T
population: Household survey; Men and women ages 15-49
intervention: ITN subsidy  and social marketing intervention  to increase knowledge,  access, and use of ITNs as part of the  Roll Back Malaria Campain. Distribution was through public health facilities.
outcomes-bf: Knowledge of malaria and ITNs, access to ITNs, beliefs about malaria protection, ownership (number of ITNs in  the household)
outcomes-behavior: Usage of  ITNs (respondent usually sleeps under a net)
smbc: 7: Customer orientation, Behavior, Insight, Exchange, Competition, Segmentation, Methods  mix

title: The  use of Insecticide-Treated bed Net in a semi-urban community in  south-south, Nigeria
authors: Ordinioha B
intervention: Social marketing of ITNs
outcomes-behavior: Of 311 ITNs sold through the  project, 18.28% were properly deployed during monitoring visit; 79.59% of properly deployed nets were  occupied by children under five

title:
Comparison of coverage with insecticide-treated nets in a
Tanzanian town and villages where nets and insecticide are either
marketed or provided free of charge
authors: Maxwell CA, Rwegoshora RT,  Magesa SM, Curtis CF
intervention: Social marketing of ITNs and insecticide
outcomes-bf: % of households that purchased a net, % of households with  intact treated nexts
outcomes-behavior: % of households reporting usage in urban and rural areas that had social marketing were compared to areas with free distribution

title: Socially marketed insecticide-treated nets effectively reduce Plasmodium infection and anaemia among children in urban Malawi
authors: Mathanga DP, Campbell CH, Taylor TE, Barlow R, Wilson ML
intervention: ITN social marketing (PSI)
outcomes-behavior: 42% of children reported ITN use the previous night
outcomes-health:
17% (295/1721) of children had a positive P. falciparum smear at enrolment. Use of ITNs was associated with 52% protective efficacy against Plasmodium
parasitemia. More than two-thirds of children were anaemic, yet the mean haemoglobin concentration
was significantly higher in children using ITNs than in those not using nets.

title: Use and misuse of a discount voucher scheme as a subsidy for insecticide-treated nets for malaria control in southern Tanzania
authors: Tami A, Mbati J, Nathan R, Mponda H, Lengeler C, Schellenberg JR
location:
Kilombero and Ulanga
districts, southern Tanzania
population:
Previously pregnant women, or primary caregivers of
children under 5 years of age, whose names were written
on a sampled voucher.
intervention:
A social marketing programme of ITNs and net treatment, including  a voucher scheme for targeting subsidies of ITNs for children under 5 years and pregnant
women through mother-and-child (MCH) clinics
outcomes-behavior:
92%
of women interviewed slept under a net during
pregnancy and of those, 26.5% had used the ITN
bought with the voucher; 65% of the women
given a voucher because they were pregnant used the ITN
acquired with that voucher during pregnancy; Of 93 households with children under 5 years, 77 (83%) reported that all under-fives (103) had slept under a net in the previous night

title: Spatial effects of the social marketing of insecticide-treated nets on malaria morbidity
authors: Abdulla S, Gemperli A, Mukasa O, Armstrong Schellenberg JR, Lengeler C, Vounatsou P, Smith T
intervention: Social marketing of ITNs
outcomes-bf: Coverage, distribution pattern and resultant spatial effects
outcomes-behavior: Percent of children using a treated net
outcomes-health:
Prevalence of parasitaemia, mild anaemia (Hb <11 g/dl) and moderate/severe anaemia (Hb <8 g/dl) in children under five; children living in areas of moderately high ITN coverage were
about half as likely to have moderate/severe anaemia

title: DEET mosquito repellent sold through social marketing provides personal protection against malaria in an area of all-night mosquito biting and partial coverage of insecticide-treated nets: a case-control study of effectiveness
authors: Rowland M, Freeman T, Downey G, Hadi A, Saeed M
location:
Behsud district, Nangahar province,
eastern Afghanistan
population: Case-control study of outpatients  with febrile illness
intervention: Social marketing of a  repellent soap containing DEET
outcomes-behavior:
Mosbar was purchased by 43% of households.
among the control group. There was a strong association between Mosbar use and ITN use, as 81% of Mosbar users also possessed ITN.
outcomes-health:
The use of Mosbar was associated with a 45% reduction in the odds of malaria 
after adjusting for ITN and other unmatched factors

title: Cost-effectiveness of social marketing of insecticide-treated nets for malaria control in the United Republic of Tanzania
authors: Hanson K, Kikumbih N, Armstrong Schellenberg J, Mponda H, Nathan R, Lake S, Mills A, Tanner M, Lengeler C
journal: Bulletin of the World Health Organization, 2003, 81(4): 269-276
population: Case-control study on child survival and demographic surveillance system
intervention: ITN and insecticide social marketing
outcomes-behavior: ITN  coverage, measured as the proportion of children that slept under a treated net the previous night, was 14% in Ulanga and 23% in Kilombero in July and August 1999.
outcomes-health: Given the estimate of 27% for protective efficacy from the case–control study, this indicates 96 deaths averted  or 2588 DALYs averted  in 1999.
smbc: 5: Customer Orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Method mix

title: Insecticide-treated bednet use, anaemia, and malaria parasitaemia in Blantyre District, Malawi
authors: Holtz TH, Marum LH, Mkandala C, Chizani N, Roberts JM, Macheso A, Parise ME, Kachur SP
population: Households with at least one child less than 5 years of age
intervention: Social marketing of ITNs (PSI)
outcomes-bf:
Bednet ownership was low
(20.5% of households)
outcomes-behavior:
Only 3.3% of rural children under 5 had slept under a net the previous night, compared
with 24.0% of urban children
outcomes-health: Rural children under 5 in households without nets experienced a statistically significant higher prevalence of malaria parasitaemia [RR  4.9] than children in households with at least one bednet
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer Orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

title: Prevention of malaria in Afghanistan through social marketing of insecticide-treated nets: evaluation of coverage and effectiveness by cross-sectional surveys and passive surveillance
authors: Rowland M, Webster J, Saleh P, Chandramohan D, Freeman T, Pearcy B, Durrani N, Rab A, Mohammed N
population: Cross-sectional surveys of housholds and passive  surveillance from clinics using case-control design
intervention: ITN  and insecticide social marketing
outcomes-behavior: Nets were purchased by 59% of families.
outcomes-health:
Cross-sectional
surveys demonstrated a 59% reduction in the risk of Plasmodium falciparum infection among ITN users compared with non-users and the passive surveillance method
showed a 69% reduction in the risk of symptomatic P. falciparum malaria among ITN users;  reductions in risk of P. vivax infection was also seen, but only statistically significant under passive  surveillance

title:
Socially-marketed rapid diagnostic tests and ACT
in the private sector: ten years of experience in
Cambodia
authors: Yeung S, Patouillard E, Allen H, Socheat D
intervention: Social  marketing of RDTs and ACT
outcomes-bf: Providers knowledge of RDTS and ACT, product availablity, sales/selling price; Consumer awareness of RDTS and ACT
outcomes-behavior: Providers selling practices and Consumer buying practices of ACTs; Providers use of RDTS
smbc: 7: Behavior, Customer Orientation,  Insight, Exchange, Competition, Segmentation, Methods Mix

title: KINET: a social marketing programme of treated nets and net treatment for malaria control in Tanzania, with evaluation of child health and long-term survival
authors: Schellenberg JR, Abdulla S, Minja H, Nathan R, Mukasa O, Marchant T, Mponda H, Kikumbih N, Lyimo E, Manchester T, Tanner M, Lengeler C
journal: Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg, 1999,  93(3): 225-31
location: Kilombero and Ulanga Districts in  South-western Tanzania
intervention: ITN and insecticide social marketing
outcomes-bf: 24% of households had at least one treated net
outcomes-behavior: 18 months after launching, 46% of 312 families with children aged under 5 years reported that their children were sleeping under treated nets
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix
